content: The Act is titled the "Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Amendments Act of 1995". It includes a statement of findings and policy. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for coal-producing States to regulate mining operations in an environmentally sound manner. States are encouraged to avoid duplication in regulatory programs and assume exclusive responsibility for permitting and enforcement of the Act with respect to surface coal mining and reclamation. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to allow coal-producing States to regulate mining operations in an environmentally sound manner, encouraging them to avoid duplication in regulatory programs and take exclusive responsibility for permitting and enforcement. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF OFFICE OF SURFACE MINING RECLAMATION AND ENFORCEMENT. Section 201(c)(1) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include administering programs for controlling surface coal mining operations, reviewing and approving State programs, conducting investigations and inspections for compliance, and issuing orders and decisions. The curr_chunk states the authority to suspend, revoke, or withhold permits for non-compliance with the Act or regulations. SEC. 4. STATE PROGRAMS. Section 503 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to allow approved State programs to apply instead of the Act for surface coal mining operations. The Act and its regulations will only apply once the State program is amended, and permittees have time to comply with any new requirements. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 allows approved State programs to apply for surface coal mining operations instead of the Act. The Act and its regulations will apply once the State program is amended, with revised or additional requirements. SEC. 5 amends Section 504(b) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. SEC. 6 adds a provision regarding compliance with environmental standards for surface coal mining operations. SEC. 7 addresses enforcement of the Act. The amendment to Section 521(a) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 shifts responsibility for enforcement to the regulatory authority, allowing for administrative and judicial review according to State law. The amendment shifts enforcement responsibility for water quality laws at surface coal mining operations to the regulatory authority approved by the EPA. SEC. 8. JUDICIAL REVIEW. The text discusses amendments to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act regarding judicial review. It states that an order of an administrative law judge will be considered a final decision subject to judicial review. Additionally, actions related to State programs will be subject to judicial review by a court of competent jurisdiction. The United States district court in the State's capital reviews the program at issue. SEC. 9 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 introduces a time limitation of three years for enforcement actions related to violations, fines, penalties, or forfeitures. This new section is added to Title VII of the Act. Additionally, SEC. 10 provides definitions for the Act. Section 701(28) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to define 'surface coal mining operation' as activities on the surface of land related to a surface coal mine or underground coal mine operations affecting interstate commerce. This includes various excavation methods like contour, strip, mountaintop removal, and the use of explosives. The definition of 'surface coal mining operation' under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 includes activities such as the use of explosives, in situ distillation, leaching, processing, and preparation of coal for interstate commerce at or near the mine site. It excludes coal extraction that is incidental to the extraction of other minerals and land where mining activities occur or disturb the natural land surface. The definition of 'surface coal mining operation' includes land surface activities such as construction of roads, excavations, impoundments, and storage areas related to mining activities. It excludes coal extraction incidental to other mineral extraction. The definition of 'surface coal mining operation' includes land surface activities related to mining activities, excluding coal extraction incidental to other mineral extraction. It does not include the construction, improvement, or use of a road designated as a public road or maintained by a governmental entity, constructed similarly to other roads of the same classification open to public use.
